etymologies: Middle English fleem, fleume, from Old French fleume, from late Latin phlegma ‘clammy moisture (of the body)’, from Greek phlegma ‘inflammation’, from phlegein ‘to burn’. The spelling change in the 16th century was due to association with the Latin and Greek

definitions: the thick viscous substance secreted by the mucous membranes of the respiratory passages, especially when produced in excessive or abnormal quantities, e.g., when someone is suffering from a cold.
shortDefinitions: thick viscous substance secreted by mucous membranes of respiratory passages

definitions: (in medieval science and medicine) one of the four bodily humors, believed to be associated with a calm, stolid, or apathetic temperament.
shortDefinitions: (in medieval science and medicine) one of four bodily humours, believed to be associated with calm, stolid

examples.text: phlegm and determination carried them through many difficult situations
